commentBody: I done did this puzz
Fun puzzle to ease into the new week.

Any puzzle with LIAM NEESON in it is okay by me, though I don't like that movie despite its fabulous cast.

I thought the puzzle had a lot of personality for a Monday and a clever theme.

If Mazda ever builds another 5 letter sports car, I'm in trouble.

Nice job, Jeffs.

I know nothing about betting, but the odds were TEN TO ONE I would do alright just because it's a gentle Monday puzzle. I also know not much about liquor but if anyone else is having an overcast Sunday afternoon of April rainshowers, I say bring out that single MALT whiskey, nibble on some slices of toasted French baguette smeared with BRIE, and listen to some TENOR SAXOPHONES wailing, as you maybe read some engaging PROSE and wile away the time. https://youtu.be/pc6CWfBgIt8?si=NEz0PWnYCzR4gJqp Thank you, Jeff & Jeff, for a very smooth puzzle and satisfying solve. Tchin tchin.
Tough for a Monday. A little over five minutes. Didn't understand the gimmick about the odd clue numbers until after I was done

Want to join my Victorian Poetry Club?
Aka “Tennyson, anyone?”

I'm curious whether it's more common for solvers to get the theme before completing the puzzle, or to complete the puzzle before getting the theme. I estimate that is solve 80% of themed puzzles without understanding the theme, and I see this same sentiment often echoed in the comments here.

Yesterday I had to understand the theme (lichee vs lychee) to get the solve, and even then only the spin but not the class part. Today, while I saw the theme, I didn't dwell on it or appreciate it until I had completed the puzzle. I tend toward the latter.
Monday easy, but not boring easy, which is not easy to construct.  Good job, Jeff and Jeffrey.  I enjoyed your puzzle.
Objection, m'lud, but the Thames does not flow through Essex.  It barely flows past it.

“Nut for a Thanksgiving pie”= myself.
I am a nut for them. All of them, any kind, any combination.

In other news, I tried making {19, 27, 45} mean something gnarly with regard to probability. 
Nope, they’re just ODD!

Pedantic editor: "Are there any news?"
Sassy reporter: "Not one new."

"What are the chances an integer is in the form 2n + 1?"
"You know the odds."

(I can't even with these puns.)

As a linguist, I must point out the difference between interpreting and translating— interpreting is done in real-time/with spoke language while translating is properly used to describe to convey meaning from one manage to another for deciphering text. 3-down clue is inaccurate.

Hard to believe no one has placed this link into the comments yet. "It's just a flesh wound." https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZmInkxbvlCs Then again, I suppose there aren't many solvers with the sense of humor of a 14-year-old boy. Except for me.
It's not just the four theme entries that are odd -- the words TEN and ONE all start in boxes with odd numbers.
my mother, an interpreter, corrects anyone who calls her a translator. different things!
That was easy, even for a Monday, but fun. Didn't notice the theme until after I'd finished.
Anyone else notice the extra space in 43D's clue? I tend to overthink and couldn't decide if it was intentional until after finding the answer. My first time seeing a potential typo.

A fun Monday puzzle that could also serve as a primer for new solvers, as it’s full of greatest hits: OPI, OREO, MIATA, OSHA, IOTA, to name just a few. “Eno” is missing, but ENOS is here! The best part is, the Jeffs have used these familiar answers in a way that is charmingly refreshing and new. OLE!
ODDS are some WELL-INTENTIONED ONE will PICK  something to knock about today’s puzzle, but I thought it was a TEN!

Twas a fun Monday!
But over too soon, a new PB time for me.
Very enjoyable though.
Just did the mini and “unique letters” was such a bad clue.

Lovely crossword.
I could even guess the baseball clue! That's a first.

Nice Monday puzzle. Just a bit on the slow side for me and the 'reveal' was just about the last thing I worked out. Just made for a nice 'oh, of course' moment. Unusual puzzle find today. A Sunday from December 30, 2001 by Elizabeth C. Gorski with the title "Dropping the ball." Probably would have been more appropriate on December 31, but that wasn't a Sunday so the puzzle wouldn't have fit. There was a seventeen letter answer down the middle of the puzzle with twelve rebus squares. In order those were: (TEN)(NINE)(EIGHT)(SEVEN)(SIX)(FIVE)(FOUR)(THREE)(TWO)(ONE)ITS(TWO)OO(TWO) And MIDNIGHT was another theme answer. Hard to describe the rest of it. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=12/30/2001&g=25&d=D I'll shut up now. ....

Nice! 
Nice to have a Monday puzzle with some long fill that one can confidently march through!
Eh. Interpreting and translating are two different things. An interpreter's job is to interpret; translator, translate. It's in the name. :)

Nice easy Monday, done in a Jeffy.
No nits to PICK.
Just enough meat for a Monday. Guess I need to start working - I guess that's one way to stay away from the news. Oh..or I could just go play in the archives.

Ah, me...over too soon.  
Unlike the stock market plunge...

I admit I checked the spaces between TEN and ONE in case those two words bracketed an ODD word, or the name of something (or someone) ODD....even though I knew it was a lot to ask on a Monday.

Congrats to Jeffrey on this nice collaboration with Jeff.  Y'all come back, hear?

Wow, two Jeffs!

This one had a nice mixture of old and new: Peter O'TOOLE and the ADDAMS Family, ASH Ketchum and EMINEM. (Though now that I think about it, Pokemon and EMINEM have been around for decades, haven't they? Am I old now?)
Take a closer look, and you’ll see the ONEs are also all on odd clue squares.
For "Pert reply" I had "yASS".

Starfleet transporter user manuals emphasize the importance of not getting too excited while operating the equipment. 

Fun Monday.

Not only do the themed answers start on an odd number (19A, 27A, 45A and 53), but the words TEN and ONE in each of these answers all start on an odd-numbered square in the grid (19, 21, 29, 31, 45, 49, 53, 55)!

Pretty Amazing!
All my friends, OPI, EGO, CEO, and APT are here… but there’s an IRA shaped hole in my heart. :p
On a rainy. Monday, my least favorite puzzle day, this crossword put a bright spot in my day, thanks to the constructors. A wonderful Monday puzzle, what are the odds?

Well, I used to get nail polish to paint rocks (a favorite summer activity) but, the brand was not OPI as the polish came from the dollar store.  And, if you have a fragile EGO avoid rock painting with accomplished artists. The Infant of Prague on a rock.... give me a break.

Nice Monday. Thanks to J&J.
On a scale of 1 to 10, this was a Monday 10. Bravo, J & J!
Today was puzzle #2000 in a row with a gold star for me :) Just back from the ACPT - puzzles are definitely my happy place right now .

A nice Monday offering. I confess I needed help understanding 24D, but as always @Steve L answered @Jane Wheeligan’s query perfectly.

A county that the Thames flows through? Well, you could have Gloucestershire, Oxfordshire, Wiltshire, Berkshire, Buckinghamshire, Surrey, Greater London, Kent, or indeed, ESSEX. Take your pick! (It’s a long river).

Nursing a squished foot today after helping a friend move her cows. Bloomin great heifer stood on me rather  walk through the wide open gate. The cow that is, not my friend. TIS but a scratch. I’ll walk it off.

Given that there was a theme, I didn’t have to type/see/read anything about current “politicians”, and I solved it in 44 minutes without any help, I’d say it’s totally worth it and great job especially for a dreary morning. I hope my fellow NYTers have a Marvellous Monday and Namaste!!
Didn’t get the theme, and the clue for OREO was weak. Otherwise, a fun puzzle!

Strands! No spoilers, plz, 'til after "view all replies"

I'm a little late getting to it today, butI enjoyed it once I figured out the theme. I needed a hint to get there.
Not half bad.

Strands #400
“Half-and-half”
💡🔵🔵🟡
🔵🔵🔵

It has become more common for themes in the NYT crossword to not really work. 
Today's puzzle: "Ten to one odds" is a phrase. OK. And then we have words that have "ten" and "one" highlighted within them, with the ten appearing prior to the one. OK. And? 
Those two elements are only vaguely related. The gag is not amusing or interesting, nor does it aid in solving. 
It's not even sensible to say that the key phrase somehow relates to the other answers. "ten to one" would imply that the ten leads TO the one, but it doesn't. It's just in the same word. 
I've got a joke for you: 
A priest, a rabbi, and a minister exist.

I see we all enjoyed this puzzle. And it also looks like most of us are having dreary weather. It’s a rainy day here in northern CA, after several days of sun and clouds. 
Thanks for a terrific Monday puzzle, Jeff and Jeff. 
I also really enjoyed all the comments. Lots of good humor, which we all need now. I started my day with a FaceTime visit with my daughter in Texas and our 3 year old grandson, and 1 year old granddaughter. They are both the funniest little munchkins! Great start to the day 🤣🥹

Nice puzzle, only 18 seconds off my best time. There was a theme? Okay, I never twigged to it, except that the shaded areas were TEN (after first rolling my eyes because Mondays are not supposed to have any twee little tricks.) Otherwise, I just rolled with this fun little Monday brain wake-up call.

Circle any letter I (eye not ell) in your completed grid. 

Now count the number of black squares in the column containing your circled I. 

If there's just one, you just beat TENTOONEODDS against you. Congratulations!

Brilliant that the constructors somehow baked this amazing feature into their construction. ;-)

Do people say "well intentioned"?  I would have thought "well intended.". Because, well, verbs.  (Fyi links to dictionary entries are, while likely well intended/intentioned, unnecessary - yes it's in MW etc.)
Why a double space 43d's clue?
As a fellow Geoff - with a G(!) - I thoroughly enjoyed this one!
Hi, I’m a pretty new solver and just want to say I solved this fun puzzle in 9 minutes, which I’m sure is molasses to experienced ones, but I am feeling very pleased! Forgive my little crow!
Is EGO always inherently inflated?

@Eddie 

And you done did it first, too!
@Vaer Agree, many better options to clue him, which now also includes The Naked Gun. https://youtu.be/_8-N8IIq_8I

@sotto voce 

Love your music picks! I can also confirm your excellent suggestions apply equally well on a rainy PNW Monday afternoon. Between the April showers and the daily news, I'm going to need a bigger bottle of single malt...

@SP 

What a Wilde idea.

/
/

@Aaron 

I started out solving the crosswords in the NY Times newspaper and was unaware that there were themes, so tend not to see them now, unless I notice one while I am solving or am hopelessly stuck and come to the column.

@Aaron What I would say is that a puzzle theme is pretty useless at first. Especially with a puzzle like yesterday.

The theme words were 12+ letters long...AND pieced together from 2 other words and a spinner.

So to even be able to use the puzzle title you need to have some decent level of groundwork which starts to make the random letters from the acrosses and downs make sense.

So i would think that that getting a foothold on the theme typically would get one towards the 40%-50% of the puzzle complete before the secret starts to reveal itself.

So one might know the form of the them answer at around that midway point.

I think on this Sunday's puzzle I knew pretty quickly exactly what the spinning space represented....Although knowing the letter direction was going to be part of the challenge.

I also think last week or so there was another themed puzzle where the type of answer was tipped off from the Title of the puzzle...Those are really just the experience of many many years of seeing puzzles.

But yeah...I think you need to typically be a sold chunk in before you can land the first theme word...not 80% of the way in...but a lot.

@Aaron
I find with an easy puzzle like in a Monday I don’t usually get the theme before hand, but with a harder puzzle the theme can be a big help. 
My favourite situation is when the theme is tricky, but one it becomes apparent it helps to solve the rest of the puzzle. 
I found yesterday’s theme was a big help.

@Aaron 

A great example of a puzzle that I think would be impossible without understanding of the theme was yesterday's (Sunday's), with the spinning classes.

@Aaron It depends on what kind of theme it is. If knowing the theme is important for figuring out some of the answers (like yesterday's theme, or a 2023 puzzle I did yesterday where there were Zs on the ends of phrases that otherwise wouldn't have Zs. If the answers don't make sense without knowing the theme, then it's important to get it pretty early on. But if, as with today's puzzle, the theme doesn't really affect the ability to solve, I generally only notice and appreciate it after I've finished.

@Cat Lady Margaret I saw the clue numbers of the TEN-ONE pair as "two" apart at 19 - 21 29 - 31 53 - 55 So, "TEN two ONE" But the TENORSAXOPHONES blew that theory out of the joint with 45 - 49. That was just ODD. But not this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sp8r2ouBIbE
@John Carson Yes I also tried to make sense f of the clue numbers but TENORSAXOMOPHONES [sic] blew that.

@Cat Lady Margaret

@Ryder H. Yes but don't you have to translate the words in your mind and then say the translation? I understand what you're saying, but it seems like kind of a nit pick when most everyone will figure out the answer from the clue. And as others have said, clues are clues, not definitions.

@Beth  I got this error as well, but I figured someone would nitpick the correction. The clue is wrong, despite the rationalizations. Interpreters maybe translate, but they also listen, think, speak. None of these answers would be correct.

@DT

@DT

Translators translate written works.
Interpreters translate in real time, usually orally. 

Dancers interpret.

@Steve L

Being less of a mensch, I tried to voice my criticism of the nit more circumspectly 🤣

I truly respect you for rightly  taking it further.

I first visited United Nations Headquarters as a young child. My father spoke three languages quite well, but even he was impressed with the skill of the interpreters there who provided simultaneous translation.

@Ryder H. 
As a Signals Intelligence Voice Interceptor (Army linguist) TRANSLATING was one of my jobs, but so was changing the oil in my Humvee.

Don't rush through even a Monday puzzle. 
Even if you've already guessed the answer, 
read the entire revealer clue.

53A [... (and the clue numbers on which they begin!)]

@mnemonica I think the revealer would have worked better without the shaded squares, but it is a Monday. I liked the repeating tens and ones but the fact that they were on odd numbers didn't help or hinder solving in any way, unless perhaps for someone who got stuck on 53a, the revealer itself.
@Sam Corbin what am I missing?  I do not understand.  Is there a clearer explanation for this theme? Usually I’m not so dense.

@gem 

The joys of Polish - there is only one word for either in our language, "tłumacz".

It may come with additional descriptors that make it clear what kind of translation is involved in the particular translator's work, but those descriptors are part rather of translators' jargon than common Polish.

For example, somebody may be a "tłumacz symultaniczny"(male)/"tłumaczka symultaniczna (female) [that's in th nominative case, even though if this sentence were in Polish, I'd be using a case we call narzędnik, the rough equivalent of which is the Latin ablativus] which is pretty much the equivalent of your "interpreter".

Random Polish trivia strikes again.

@gem 

That wasn’t the clue. We’re not talking about what the name of the job is.
@Erin N. Looked ok to me?

BTW, the Mazda is not called Miata in Poland - it's always been sold as an MX-5 (not MX-5 Miata, just MX-5). I know the American name though, but I'm wondering where from? Maybe some older Need for Speed games :D

Kyle, Are you objecting to the use of "unique" in the clue? If so, why? https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/unique
I thought the clue was clever but when I saw it I immediately skipped past figuring it would be a time sink.  As it was I plugged in fiGht at 6A which blew up the game anyway (1:42).  Oh well.

@Barry Ancona 

I object to "fittingly".

@Jane Wheelaghan 

Glad to see my verbosity came to serve a purpose!
@Jane Wheelaghan the creme in the middle of the Oreo. I guess they probably did trademark it. Some of them are "double-stuf".

@Amy 

The last time this came up somebody pointed out the indecency of the name - it implies there is double stuffing compared to a normal Oreo, but there is less than that... And it's "ok" because "stuf" means nothing. American brands ❤️

@Jane Wheelaghan 

UNEARNED EUNS are only remotely like an “own goal” in soccer. 

In baseball, only the team at bat can score runs. The other team is in the field, and their intention is to get outs. Every inning, each team gets its turn, and each turn ends when the defensive team gets three outs. 

If a defensive player commits an error, which means they drop a ball they should have caught, or throw a ball away, or something similar, the runs the team scores after the point they should have made three outs are called UNEARNED RUNS. They’re just as good as earned runs, but they don’t count against the pitcher’s statistics. 

Every game has an official scorer, usually a sportswriter, who decides whether a play is a hit or an error. 

Hope that helps!

Next time you’re in NY, I can take you to a baseball game, like I’ve been promising Andrzej.

@Steve L 
The only similarity is I suppose that an error benefits the other side?

I'm afraid I don't get your second paragraph, but no matter. 
So the fielders only need to get 3 players out? In cricket the whole team needs to be out, in the traditional game. That's why it takes so long. Shorter games are played now to make it more appealing.
The pitcher gets credit for the runs? Not the batter?
I would call a 'sportswriter' a journalist - is this what you mean? 
This is so puzzling!
A visit to NY - possible after January 2029.....
Thank you!

@Steve L 
Ooh, ooh, can I come too? 🙆‍♀️

@Helen Wright 
Start saving ...

@Jane Wheelaghan 
We’ve got four years…

@Helen Wright

@Francis 
Claim asylum. You’ll get free accomodation 😃

@Andrzej 
Yeah, no. Too risky. Plus the food is terrible! Or so all the prison films I’ve seen claim.

@Francis 

Well, if you're comfortably retired, you should be able to afford living in a place like Poland. We have hundreds of thousands of expats living in Warsaw alone, so I'm sure we would welcome another one.

@Helen Wright 

The portion sizes are shocking to a European, but on either of our US trips in 2011 and 2013 we had no problems finding good quality restaurants - some were excellent, actually. The supermarket food was scary though - ingredients unfit for human consumption under European law were everywhere, and so much stuff was highly processed, with so many additives you wouldn't believe.

@Jane Wheelaghan 

There are nine innings in every baseball game, or even more if the score is tied after nine. In each inning, the defense has to get three outs. Each turn (or half inning, as both teams must have a turn) normally lasts about five to fifteen minutes. A game takes about three hours. Batters usually wind up having three to five turns per game, depending on how many runners get on base each inning. 

There is a batter’s statistic for runs (scored by the batter) and for runs batted in (RBI), which are runs scoring as a result of his batting (meaning the base runners and the batter himself who were able to score thanks to the batter’s hits). The latter description is a bit of an oversimplification, but I figure you can still get the general idea. 

The pitcher’s statistic is the ERA (Earned Run Average), which is a measure of his effectiveness. Earned runs only because UNEARNED RUNS are not his fault. In this case, as in golf scores, the lower the number is, the better. 

An ERA of 2.00 is exceptional, meaning that a pitcher has given up an average of 2 runs per nine-inning game. Normal is in the 3 to 4 range, and above that, you probably won’t have a job next season. 

Hope this helps, and doesn’t confuse you even more.

@Helen Wright 

Of course you can!

@Francis
Scotland is beautiful if June. I hope the whisky industry still exists by then. By the way, we call it ‘whisky’ not ‘Scotch’!

@Kristopher 
Yes indeed. That's a REALLY good way to annoy the heck out of an interpreter---calling them a "translator".

@Oikofuge 

But translating is part of what an interpreter does, and that's what the clue was about.

@Oikofuge 

It *is* the crossword's comment board, isn't it?

I know what you mean, but the bottom line is, an interpreter is a kind of translator. That statement is not false.

I sometimes tease my programmer mate by calling him an IT guy. How he hates that 🤣. But while some programmers are IT guys and some are not (my mathematician friend is a programmer but not an IT guy), all interpreters are translators, if ones with additional skills necessary for interpreting. Not all translators are interpreters, but all interpreters are translators.

@Oikofuge 

Keep in mind that you can’t use any form of translate in the clue.

@Andrzej 
"It *is* the crossword comment board, isn't it?"
That explains all the discussion about quilts, cats and the weather ...

These are all fine, of course. But any attempt to have a discussion about word usage seems to immediately run against the buffers of "Yes, but it's a crossword." I saw it happen to you, the other day, when mangled Latin was deemed to be OK *because it was appearing in an American crossword puzzle*.

And now here I am, apparently having to "defend" drawing attention to a real-world distinction that is important to its practitioners (both interpreters and translators) and which might perhaps be of interest to those who are interested in language and care to think about these things.
 
[Here, I've deleted a long dissertation on the difference between "translating" and "being a translator". This is not a forum that lends itself to that sort of thing. I'll let it rest.]

@Andrzej I guess interpreters don’t like to be called “just a translator” the way an administrative assistant doesn’t want to be called “just a secretary”. But this is definitely a case of TCS (Too Close Syndrome). The number one meaning of “translate” is “to turn into one's own or another language”. Isn’t that what interpreters do? https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/translate
@Kristopher Specifically, a translator deals with written text while an interpreter deals with spoken words.
@Steve L That analogy is conflated and flawed. Interpreting and translating are two different concepts. You'd be better off differing a painter and a sculptor.

@Steve L 
In the real world, rather than Crosslandia, TCS is often translated as NAKEAISMJKYOTYS ("Not Actually Knowing Enough About It, So Maybe Just Keep Your Opinion To Yourself Syndrome").

(That's a real thing in my neck of the woods, BTW.)

[You should picture me smiling pleasantly while typing the above. Because that's what I'm doing.]

@Kristopher I used to work with a Japanese bank. When they came to our US office, they always brought a) gifts and b) a person we referred to as an intepreter. That person listened to what each person said and conveyed it back in the other language. Are you saying that person is not translating? Or would you say that person is not an interpreter? No snark intended, I'm genuinely curious.

@Oikofuge 

The anecdote behind the identification of NAKEAISMJKYOTYS  as a clinical entity is perhaps worth sharing.
A Professor of English Literature decided to take the student nurse who was caring for him to task over her usage of what he called "affected, obfuscatory medical jargon", on the basis of his knowledge of dictionary definitions.
He could have chosen many, many valid targets, but unfortunately singled out a couple of terms of art that had subtle gradations of meaning in medicine, of which he was understandably unaware.
So I arrived just as she was delivering herself of the phrase, "Look, you don't actually ..." in particularly steely tones.

We never actually made an award, but the discussion of nominations for the NAKEAISMJKYOTYS Award were a frequent source of entertainment in the bleak small hours of an overnight ICU shift.

@Cyndie Good question! Spoken communication is interpreted. Written communication is translated. That individual, if speaking spoken communication, was interpreting and therefore an interpreter. If they were dealing with written communication, they would be translating, and therefore a translator. Hope this helps!
@Kristopher That helps, thanks!

@Mean Old Lady 

Ouch, picking on the foreigner :(

Mean Old Lady indeed!!!

:D

I would find it fiendishly difficulty to translate that - because I see the need for interpretation, but the finer points of "bless your heart" are lost one me. I won't google it to cheat my way out of this, but I think it can be said either sincerely (probably by a nice old lady? ;p) or ironically, by, say, a mean old lady. I'd need context to understand a specific case better. Once I'd have it, I'd come up with a Polish equivalent.

Seriously though, I don't see how that is not translation. Take a simple analogy: translating a poem is done in writing, and not simultaneously, but it involves a whole lotta interpretation: usually a translated poem is very different from the original, because it was translated - and interpreted! - by another poet, who expressed themself in the translation. I know Goethe's Erlkönig in German and in a Polish translation by the Nobel prize winner Wisława Szymborska. It's two different poems, really.

The whole translation/interpretation dichotomy is a false one, IMO. All translation - except when done badly by underqualified poeple or AI - involves interpretation.

@Kristopher 

No, it doesn’t help. Oral “interpretation” is translating. It’s not something else. It’s literally insane to say it’s not. 

I am fluent in Spanish and worked in a school as an ESL and Spanish teacher, and whenever someone (such as a parent) required an oral translation, someone asked me to come over and translate. I was acting as an “interpreter” for the moment, but I was translating from one language to another and back. It’s disingenuous to say that people don’t say that oral interpretation is translation. Because they do. And because it is. 

I also did a great deal of written translation as well. 

Dancers interpret. So do literary analysts. Neither of them translate. But language interpreters do.

People are just talking past each other, here.

@Kristopher is talking about "interpreting" as the ENTIRE SKILL-SET of a professional interpreter, and "translating" as the ENTIRE SKILL-SET of a professional translator. 
In the big Venn diagram of skill-sets, the "interpreter" set overlaps the "translator" set in a region @Steve L calls "translating"---which is to say, the process of substituting words in one language for words in another.
But the "interpreter" and "translator" regions contain large unshared sets of skills which differentiate @Kristopher's usage of "interpreting" from @Kristopher's usage of "translating", which are both different from @Steve L's usage of "translating".

No-one is insane, no-one is disingenuous. You're just using the same words to MEAN DIFFERENT THINGS.

@Mike Interesting. I’ve definitely used both, but I’m struggling to figure out what determines which expression I use. Maybe a person can be WELL INTENTIONED but a thing is well intended? It l feels wrong if i say, for instance, “The plan was well intentioned.”

but now i’ve thought about it for too long and everything sounds wrong. hm.

@Mike "Well-intentioned" is actually more commonly used than "well-intended" (with or without the hyphens) in both American English and British English, according to Google Ngram. There seems to be an effort to reserve "well-intended" for actions and inanimate things, and "well-intentioned" for people, but it's imperfect. Some real-world research here: https://english.stackexchange.com/questions/226582/usage-of-well-intended-vs-well-intentioned 'The results for the recent block of Google Books matches work out to seventeen animate and eleven inanimate objects connected to "well-intentioned," and one animate and fourteen inanimate objects connected to "well-intended." These results indicate that many writers (and their editors) probably make the same distinction between "well-intentioned" for animate things and "well-intended" for inanimate things that the OP does. Still, it seems clear that "well-intentioned" has always (since 1803, anyway) been applied to a significant degree to both animate and inanimate things, while the preference for limiting "well-intended" to inanimate things has always been quite strong.'
